"Consider implementing crop rotation to maintain soil health and prevent pest and disease buildup. This technique involves planting different crops in the same area in different seasons or years, which helps to replenish nutrients and reduce the risk of pests and diseases."

"Incorporate natural pest control methods such as companion planting, using beneficial insects, and creating natural barriers. Companion planting involves planting certain crops together that repel or attract pests, while beneficial insects such as ladybugs and lacewings can help control pest populations. Natural barriers such as rows of plants or netting can also help to prevent pest infestations."

"Utilize cover crops to improve soil health and fertility. Cover crops are planted primarily to manage soil erosion, fertility, quality, water, weeds, pests, diseases, biodiversity and wildlife - they can also help to fix nitrogen in the soil, which is essential for plant growth."

"Implement a composting program to reduce waste and improve soil health. Composting involves breaking down organic matter such as kitchen scraps, yard waste, and other materials into a nutrient-rich soil amendment that can be used to improve soil structure, fertility, and water retention."

"Consider using raised beds or containers to improve drainage and prevent soil-borne diseases. Raised beds are elevated above the ground, which helps to improve drainage and prevent soil-borne diseases. Containers can also be used to grow plants in well-draining soil, which is essential for healthy plant growth."
